We use Hugo to format and generate our website, the Docsy theme for styling and site structure, and Azure DevOps (ADO) to manage the deployment of the site.
All submissions, including submissions by project members, require review. We use pull requests for this purpose. Consult ADO Help for more information on using pull requests.
Updating a single page If you’ve just spotted something you’d like to change while using the docs, Docsy has a shortcut for you:
 Click Edit this page in the top right hand corner of the page. If you don’t already have an up to date fork of the project repo, PLEASE CREATE ONE. The appropriate page in your fork is displayed in edit mode.  Previewing your changes locally If you want to run your own local Hugo server to preview your changes as you work:
  Follow the Hugo Quick Start to install Hugo. You’ll need at least Hugo version 0.45 (we recommend using the most recent available version), and it must be the extended version, which supports SCSS.
  Download and install node.js
  Fork the Chapter repo repo into your own project, then create a local copy using git clone. Don’t forget to use --recurse-submodules or you won’t pull down some of the code you need to generate a working site.
git clone --recurse-submodules --depth 1 https://dev.azure.com/robdyke0245/_git/chapter   Run hugo server in the site root directory. By default your site will be available at http://localhost:1313/. Now that you’re serving your site locally, Hugo will watch for changes to the content and automatically refresh your site.
  Continue with the usual Git PR workflow to edit files, commit them, push the changes up to your fork, and create a pull request.
  Creating an issue If you’ve found a problem in the docs, but you’re not sure how to fix it yourself, please create an issue in the Chapter repo. You can also create an issue about a specific page by clicking the Create Issue button in the top right hand corner of the page.
Useful resources  [Docsy user guide](wherever it goes): All about Docsy, including how it manages navigation, look and feel, and multi-language support. Hugo documentation: Comprehensive reference for Hugo. Github Hello World!: A basic introduction to GitHub concepts and workflow.

Platform Engineering Chapter The platform engineering chapter in CIS aims to enable customers to build and operate platforms on hybrid cloud environments. In order to succeed in this, the skills and culture need to be developed and integrated into the way that engineers at Capgemini deliver service.
Chapter The chapter is focusing on developing the attitude and priciples essential to successful platform engineering teams’ ways of working.
The original Spotify paper in 2012, described the underlying concept of chapters:
Chapters: Henrik Kniberg & Anders Ivarsson, Spotify 2012   A key tenant though is Aligned Autonomy
The Platform Engineering Chapter is therefore focusing on CIS SME’s and Architects, working closing with the rest of Capgemini, to identify and develop the skills and capabilities required to be able to deliver the best platforms for customers.
Capgemini and our customers have a multitude of platform engineering teams, with the knowledge and experience captured within different business units, and knowledge repositories. The Chapter is also looking to facilitate the sharing and awareness of these.
Platform Engineering As organisations migrate their IT workloads to various types of public, private and hybrid clouds, platform teams have evolved. A core focus of all organisations is to enable the application (or ‘product’) teams to be more efficient and effective, delivering quality business features quicker. Tjhere are a multitude of views in how that efficiency could be achieved, such as the papter from Peter Seibel or the description from ThoughtWorks
An initial architectural overview to consider from the CIS perspective is
  Whereby the platform team will develop accelerators and stacks to provide environments that support the application and data engineering team
Growth & Development In order to achive this the Chapter is looking to
 Develop skills Develop accelerators for platform deployments and operation  The training programes and accelerators to deliver on this capability is captured throughout this site.

This is a generated static site The first website I hand-crafted with Notepad was a static web site. Painfully static. Made slightly less painful with version control and helper bash scripts. I was an early convert to web content management systems with WYSIWYG editors such as Drupal & Wordpress. Until I had to run them at scale.
This site is built using Hugo, a general-purpose website framework written in Go. Technically speaking, Hugo is a static site generator. Unlike systems that dynamically build a page with each visitor request, Hugo builds pages when you create or update your content.
Show the thing The content is written in markdown, stored in a git repo in Azure DevOps and published using a release pipeline.
